subject: RE: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or IsCollection.isEmpty()
msgSnippet: David, ... I wouldn t say that the intent is less clear, but having to go back to the old assert methods for this one case seems very messy to me.  In my
messageBody:
David,



>Is the intent less clear in

>
>assertTrue(list.isEmpty())?



I wouldn't say that the intent is less clear, but having to go back to
the "old" assert methods for this one case seems very messy to me. In
my mind, Hamcrest is a completely new way to write all the JUnit
asserts. Having to go back to assertTrue makes me wonder what other
features of the old asserts are not replicated in Hamcrest. In
addition, it reminds me of how much I didn't like old assert model J,
particularly how I could never remember where the expected and actual
values went in the assertEqual functions J (back when I first learned
JUnit, Eclipse hadn't yet been invented, and we coded in Emacs using the
old JUnit test runner from 3.x).



>Let me take this in a different direction. I've wanted, for a while,
>to be able to say
>
>assertThat(list).isEmpty();
>
>Using imposterization, this is possible to write, and gives the
>wonderful bonus that failure messages can be hamcrest-level
>informative, like:
>
>Expected: x.isEmpty()
>Actual: x = [a, b, c]



This looks like a wonderful idea, most certainly because it allows users
to use all of Hamcrest without having to write thousands of "import
static" statements. Also, it seems like it would be much easier to find
all the Hamcrest features because they would all be available from a
single entry point rather than from multiple classes. I also like the
fact that this would make error reporting that much easier.



Rocco

Rocco,

On Thu, May 14, 2009 at 10:08 AM, Pigneri, Rocco <rpigneri@...
<mailto:rpigneri%40mda-data.com> > wrote:
> First off, I apologize if my formatting makes this e-mail hard to
read.
> I have been having trouble getting the formatting to work over the
> listserv. Secondly, I apologize if I come off as overly assertive:

(FYI, you don't. You state your opinion, the strength of your
conviction, and supporting arguments. I couldn't ask for less.)

(And I kind of hope, given the context, that "assertive" was intended
as a pun. :-)

> I strongly disagree. One of the great strengths of the Hamcrest
system
> is the natural readability and self-documentation of the asserts, and
> the proposed change only enhances that. It's important to look at
these
> use cases from the point of view of the user. For example, in the
> following examples
>
>
>
> assertThat(list.isEmpty());
>
> assertThat(flagNotSet);
>
> assertThat(objectIsNull && listIsEmpty);

Is the intent less clear in

assertTrue(list.isEmpty())?

Let me take this in a different direction. I've wanted, for a while,
to be able to say

assertThat(list).isEmpty();

Using imposterization, this is possible to write, and gives the
wonderful bonus that failure messages can be hamcrest-level
informative, like:

Expected: x.isEmpty()
Actual: x = [a, b, c]

I've created this functionality a number of times, but haven't gotten
around to figure out how to package it: I'm not sure that the number
of dependencies it brings on board would be worth the addition to core
JUnit, but if an interested listener would like to create an extension
package, I'd be one of the first users.

David Saff
